tagDescription: Lord Ashburton to T. Baring. The Jaudon difficulties - His opinion on their Banking system.
Ad.de Bacourt: Personal.
Edward Lawford: Question of settling commercial debts.
Egerton Baines: Offers his services for extracting of morphium from opium for China trade.
T.W. Ward to Lord Ashburton. Concerning Daniel Webster and his proposed trip to England. Press Copy.
L. Mariategui & Co.: Encloses circular informing of changes in firm.
S.S. Gair to C.B. Young: Railway steel.
Overend, Gurney & Co.: Acknowledging receipt of 9,754 pounds.
Resolution relative to the Payment of Interests on Public Loans (Pennsylvania).
T. Baring: Stock market.
John C. Spencer, Secretary of State, to Erastus Corning: The States of New York will not borrow money.
T.W. Ward to Wm. P. Grayson, Mississippi Union Bank: Will negotiate bills for the account of the bank.
Sam F. Maccracken: Distribution of the State of Ohio stocks.
C.A.Davis to J.Bates - Describes the financial state of the country &c.
Adrien Lestapis: Business matters.
W.W. de Forest: Referring to St. Croix sugar estate.
A.E. Perez: Enclosing report addressed to Prince d'Anglona of 12 February 1840.
Francis Thomas, President Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Co. to George Peabody - on affairs of the Canal Co.
Canal Tolls - The amounts received for tolls, penalties and copies of clearances on the New York State Canals.
Joseph Coolidge, Jr.: Arrangement for trading in Canton.

C.A. Davis to J.Bates - The state of the country financially and politically - Comments on the Bank of United States and Jaudon. N.B. Filed with this is a press copy 10 January 1840 of Mr. Bates' reply with his explanation of their connection with Jaudon
F.H. Elmore, Bank of State of South Carolina: Visit of General Hamilton to London.
T. Baring: Gives quotations of select American stocks.
Richard Willing: Meeting of shareholders of the Bank of United States.
Overland, Gurney & Co.: Receipt of 31,000 pounds Maryland Bonds.
Geo. McDuffie: Fixes limits for disposition of South Carolina Bonds.
Geo. McDuffie to J. Bates. Protesting against procedure of Baring Bros. & Co. with regard to returning the South Carolina bonds to their agent in the United States.
Roswell L. Colt, New York to General John D'Everoux, London: Draft protested.
Joshua Bates to H. Mildmay - Refers to the McLeod Case and to the Report of the American Commissioners on the North East Boundary.

Extracts of letters of 7 January 1839, 14 January 1839, 2 March 1840, 14 March 1840, 1 April 1840, 18 May 1840, 6 December 1839, 2 January 1840, 20 April 1840, 18 June 1840 from Baring Bros. & Co. to C.H. Marshall: About remittances on account.
Francis Thomas, Pres. Chesapeake & Ohio Canal Co. to George Peabody: The affairs of the canal.
George Peabody: Offer the purchase 6,000 pounds worth of Maryland Bonds for private party.
Daniel Webster to J. Bates - Interesting comments on current events - political and financial - refers to Maine boundary dispute &c. N.B. Filed with it is press copy of Mr. Bates' reply.
Statement of Alabama State Stocks. Signed - John J. Palmer, Agent.
John Rae Reid, Governor of the Bank of England, to Baring Bros. & Co. Concurring in their views in relation to the exchange operations contemplated with Paris - subject to certain conditions.
Unsigned extract of letter from Grant & Stone.
W. Rathbone to S.S. Gair: Gives letter of credit to Augustine Nunez, Carthagena.
Palmer, McKillop, Dent & Co. Relating to the Louisville, Cincinnati & Charleston R.R. Co.
Edward Austin to T.W. Ward: Cotton trade.
Geo. B. Blake & Co.: Mr. E.W.R. Lyman to represent them in England.
Josiah Quincy, Western Railroad Co. Satisfaction over sale of state bonds.
F. Curwen to J. Bates - Describes certain stocks that he wishes to deposit with them for sale.
Overend, Gurney & Co.: Have placed name on list for 100,000 pounds Bond of the United States Bank.
Illinois State Debt and Finances. Extract from the Commercial Bulletin St. Louis Mo. 8 October 1840.
Geo. McDuffie to J. Bates - re financial affairs of State of South Carolina - and comments on the cotton investments.
R.C. Hooper: Expects promising prospects for sugar in Cuba; encloses copy of letter to T.W. Ward of 3 December 1839.
Statement of the Debt of Louisiana.
Memo acknowledging the receipt by Mr. Loyd of 31,250 Maryland Bonds.

Richard Willing to Baring Bros. & Co. Regarding his having forwarded the Report of the Investigating Committee- His opinion of the affairs of the Bank United States. Enclosed also letter of 30 April 1841.
A.H.Lawrence to J.Bates re his becoming a partner in the firm of Messrs. Buchanan Bros., sons of the British Consul in New York.
M.T. Williams to Baring Bros. & Co. Re affairs of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois States.
Copies of letters of Joseph Coolidge, J.M. Forbes, J.P. Cushing, Hogua, and J.C.G. pertaining to the trade with China.
Hugo C. Gildemeister: Asks for credit for iron business.
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ to Baring Bros. & Co. In relation to New York City Securities &c. The Croton aqueduct &c. N.B. The last page of this letter is missing.
Louis McLane: Desires to settle notes promptly.
Joseph Coolidge: Arrangements for trading at Canton.

Copy of advertisement United States Gazette: Dissolution of the Houses of Alexander Brown & Sons of Baltimore, John A. Brown & Co. of Philadelphia, Brown Brothers & Co. of New York and W.&J. Brown & Co. of Liverpool.
Union Bank, Louisiana.
President Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. concerning iron required.
Baltimore & Ohio R.R. Co. Bond for 500 pounds. See printed matter, 1 July 1839.
C.A. Davis: Business and political news.
Henry G. Chapman: Business affairs.
R.B. Forbes: Thinks Mr. Coolidge will not come out to Canton.
C. Guillemin to T.W. Ward: Refers to the settlement of the estate of Mr. Knight at Havana.
E.A.K. Ward Meath: Memo of securities returned by J. Bates.
Charles H. Forbes to Baring Bros. & Co. Enclosing paper re Texas affairs, addressed to the President, Mirabeau Lamar.

John A. Stevens to J. Bates - Enclosing a statement of the Bank of Commerce, New York, In order to refute an article in the Herald purporting that that Bank had a heavy suspended debt &c. Sgd/ Geo. Curtis, Cashier. Refers to McLeod Case.
James Brickhead: Coffee market; mode of payment; political news.
C.A. Davis to J. Bates - Rumours of war between France and England and the possible effect upon United States &c.
F.W. Schmidt, Manchester: Cotton market
Giles F. Yates to Baring Bros. & Co. Re unclaimed dividend upon Government Stock owned by them twenty years ago.
T. Baring: General financial matters.
Wm. Appleton to J. Bates - Comments on the consequences of the derangement of the affairs of the United States Bank.
C.A. Davis: Political and financial news in the United States.
Jno. A. Stevens to J. Bates - Comments on affairs of Bank United States - and financial affairs generally.

Thomas Baring to Baring Bros. & Co. Comments upon Indiana business - Formation of a Company for the administration of American stocks - Hottinguer & Co., Baguenault & Co., Delessert & Co. & Mr. Dassier - N.B. See 14 March 1840 for Prospectus &c.

E.&M. Pontifex and J. Wood to Baring Bros. & Co. Circular letter re their Patent Vacuum Pan for making sugar by evaporating the Cane Juice. Enclosing copy of Paper read at the Academy of Sciences at Paris by M. Eugene Peligot on the composition of the Sugar Cane.
Goodhue & Co., New York to Warren Delano Jr., Canton: arrangements for trading at Canton.
T.J. Fox Alden to Sir Francis Baring - Details of his banking scheme.
George Peabody: Further on Maryland's tax bill.
John McVickers to J. Bates - Introducing Rev. B.B. Killikelly DD and forwarding by him his pamphlet on a "National Bank" - Refers to meeting Lord Sydenham.
J.S. Cronin, Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Co.: Encloses copy of the Act of the Maryland Legislature.
Enlargement of The Erie Canal.
T. Baring: American securities.
T. Baring: Memo and Dividend certificate relating to the administration of foreign stocks by Messrs. Baguenault and Co. and Associates.
Gracie & Sargent: Expects low prices for cotton in the future.
List of firms with outstanding credits; overdue loans covered and uncovered.
J.M. Forbes. Enclosing correspondence relative to trouble in the firm of Russell & Co. caused by leaving out Joseph Coolidge.

A. Ledoux & Co. to Sir Francis Baring - Proposing a compromise in the matter of the New Orleans property, once owned by General La Fayette and now claimed by the Barings as well as by them. N.B. Some interesting details.
Edward Austin: Press copy of letter relating to shipment of cotton. Enclosed letter to T.W. Ward of 8 December 1840.
John D. Bates: Ward refused covered credit.
Joshua Bates: Comments on American economic matters; Unites States Bank, securities of various states, cotton, political news.
State of the Merchants' Bank, New Orleans.
Debt of the City of New York - Extracts from the Annual Report of the New York City Comptroller.
Thomas Baring to Baring Bros. & Co. Re American Stocks &c.
Thomson, Stankey & Co. Introducing Mr. Keating of the Philadelphia & Reading Railroad Co.
J.M. Forbes: Joseph Coolidge's visit to England; opium market.
Jos. Coolidge, Jr. to T.W. Ward. Concerning the Chinese situation.
Thomas Maingay: Investment in American securities.
A. & G. Ralston & Co.: Informs of draft for £1,975.
S.S. Gair to Baring Bros. & Co. Enclosing statement of the probable proceeds of the cotton on account of the Union Bank of Mississippi.
Denison & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Forwarding letter from Mr. Jaudon re stocks to be deposited with them and the conditions attached.
Extracts of letters from Baring Bros. & Co. to the President of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Co.
Lewis Loyd: Purchase of $1,200,000 New York State stock.
Gracie & Sargent to Baring Bros. & Co. Notifies them that their firm is dissolved - Mr. Welles of Paris and Mr. Sargent retiring - the house to be continued by Mr. Gracie.
Unsigned Memo respecting the course which the Philadelphia Bank of the United States will pursue in regard to the resumption of specie payments.
N.M. Rothschild & Sons: Acknowledges receipt of American securities.
T.W. Ward to T. Dunlap - letters and memos relating to troubles with the Bank and their London agent, Mr. Jaudon.
James Lee & Co.: Encloses remittance and asks to continue offering credit under previous arrangement.
J.E. Thayer: Dull business because of bad state of the United States Bank.
Louis McLane: Expects Legislature of Maryland to provide funds for payment of state debts.
Extracts of Letters from Baring Bros. & Co. to the President of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Co.
Lord Ashburton to J. Bates. Discusses policy to be adopted re Bank of United States and Jaudon Difficulties.
Geo. Peabody to T. Baring - Resenting as unjust, remarks made by him re sale of Maryland Bonds.
Joseph Coolidge: Arrival at Quebec and other matters.
Edward Cruft: Acceptance of drafts.
J.M. Forbes: Warren Delano joins the firm of Russell & Co. at Canton.
George Peabody: Purchase of 300,000 pounds of Maryland Bonds.
J.B. Murray: North American Trust and Banking Co. charged with breach of faith.
M.T. Williams, Ohio Life Insurance & Trust Co., Cincinnati: Feels results of elections inspired confidence in fiscal and commercial system.
Louis McLane: About the sale of Maryland stock.
Copy of contract for $2,000,000 Bonds of the Louisville, Cincinatti and Charleston R.R. Co. entered with Palmers & Co.
Geo. B. Reese: Will resume their English business.
T. Baring: Financial affairs; securities market.
Wm. De Forest to J. Bates - Information re the St. Croix Estate.
Geo. Peabody: Encloses copy of Act of the Maryland Legislature. (See 2 December 1839).
Arch. Gracie to T.W. Ward: Order to buy 10,000 bales of cotton.
T. Baring: Had conversation with Dassier about marketing American securities in Paris.
Thomas L.L. Brent to Baring Bros. & Co. Offers his services as guide in their commercial and monetary operations - comments upon several questions - Slavery, National Bank, Internal Improvement &c.
Ad. de Bacourt: Departure for the United States.

George Peabody to Baring Bros. & Co. Enclosing copy of letter containing terms upon which Baring Bros. & Co. agree to buy 300,000 pounds Maryland Sterling Bonds from him as agent of the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal Co.
R.M. Blatchford: Louis McLane will negotiate on behalf of the Baltimore and Ohio Rail Road Company for 2-3 millions of Maryland State stock.
T. Baring: Cotton business; American securities.
A. Dassier: American securities.
Sam. F. Maccracken to Baring Bros. & Co. Re a loan for the State of Ohio for completing public works.
R.R. Hunter, United States Consulate, Cowes to J. Bates - Enclosing letter of instructions to Mr. John Knowles, who is to be left in charge of Consulate during his absence.
Mitchell King, President Louisville Cincinnati & Charleston Railroad Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. re Bonds of Louisville, Cincinnati & Charleston Railroad Company.
Geo. Peabody to Baring Bros. & Co. Maryland Bonds retained in the United States for the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal Co.
T. Baring: Market for American securities.

S. Jaudon to Baring Bros. & Co. Relative to a letter in the Times of 24 December 1839, Signed - "A Genevese Traveller", making certain charges against him and also involving the Baring Bros. N.B. In the printed documents under date 24 December 1839 will be found a Pamphlet entitled - Extract from a letter signed - "A Genevese Traveller".
Merchants Bank, New Orleans - Statement.
Henry G. Chapman: Informs of draft for 160 pounds.
Palmers, McKillop, Dent & Co.: Refers to securities deposited on behalf of Sam Jaudon.
State debts and remarks.
Manning & Marshall, Mexico, Re offer for the quicksilver contract.
C.A. Davis to J. Bates - Political comments - Mr. Clay's Land Bill - Bank of United States & c.
C.A. Davis to J. Bates on the subject of currency - The political situation.
B. Gayle, Bank State of Alabama to Wm. R. Hallett: Cites proposed law covering prompt payment of the Alabama 6% Bonds.
Louis McLane to Baring Bros. & Co. Enclosing copy of Law of Maryland appointing them agent for the payment of the principle and interest on its public debt.
Thomas Baring: Market for American securities.
Kraentler & Mieville: Report one of the bills was protested.

Thomas Baring to Baring Bros. & Co. Enclosing the prospectus of the administration for the issue of foreign funds in Bonds to bearer, established in Paris by Baguenault & Cie. A. Dassier; Delessert & Cie & Hottinguer & Co. - and copy of their provisional certificate (French & English).
H. Lavergne, President Consolidated Association of Planters, Louisiana, to Baring Bros. & Co. Re purchase by them for account of the Bank the State Bonds redeemable by the Association in June 1843.
B.M. Carter: Wishes to sell the Bank United States stock.

M.T. Williams, President Ohio Life Insurance & Trust Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Company's satisfaction with their course as to Ohio Stocks, Financial affairs of Pennsylvania - New appointments to the Board of Commissioners of Chesapeake & Ohio Canal fund - Establishment of Office in New York under the direction of Mr. Perkin.
John Kenyon: Order for £38,000 Massachusetts Bonds. Encloses letter from Edward Kenyon to Daniel Webster asking for support with J. Bates.
F.B. Wells, Macao to Messrs. Goodhue & Co.: Extracts of letters relating to the damaged cargo of Capt. Benson.
A.B. Shankland: (?) Patent on planning device.
C.A. Davis: Financial and political news.
Copy of correspondence between members of the firm of Borie, Bohlen & Co. and T.W. Ward re terms on which their business was to be carried on.
H.S. Mildmay: Suspension of the Banks in Philadelphia; exports from the United States may help the exchange transactions.
Daniel Webster to T.W. Ward: About title to lands mortgages to J. Bates.
F. Curwen to Baring Bros. & Co. The cotton market.
Silas E. Burrows to John Baring - Protesting against certain remarks about him made by Baring Bros. & Co. in a letter to Grinnell, Minturn & Co. and enclosing copy of his letter to the latter.
Overend, Gurney & Co.: Referring to the $1,200,000 New York State stock.
George Peabody: State of Maryland bonds.
Lord Ashburton to T. Baring - His private opinion with regard to the Texas Loan.
Gracie & Sargent: prospect of large cotton crop in the South.
Josiah Quincy: Can dispose of Massachusetts bonds on local market.

J.J. Dixwell to J. Bates - Thinks Jaudon's letter of December not sufficiently strong in its defence of Mr. Bates & Baring Bros. & Co. Recommends his brother George Basil Dixwell to the employed in the service of Baring Bros. & Co. in India.
Extract from the Report from the Indiana Commissioners concerning the State Debt.

George Mackubin, Treasurer Western Shore Md. to Francis Thomas, President Chesapeake & Ohio Canal Co. Denying that he has given any authority to Mr. McLane to make the coupons of the States sterling Bonds payable at any particular house in London.
T. Baring to Baring Bros. & Co. French Political affairs.
Alfred Clarke: Comments on forth-coming Presidential election.
A. Dassier to J. Bates - re Indiana affairs &c.
H. Lavergne, Cons. Association of Planters of Louisiana: Caterpillars damaged crops.
George Peabody: State of Maryland bonds.

George Peabody: The sale of Maryland bonds; encloses letter from G.S. Washington, Pres. Chesapeake & Ohio R.R. Co. of 19 April 1838; a report of the President and Directors of 4 June 1838; letters dated 5 May 1838, 27 July 1839, 19 October 1839, 9 November 1839, 13 November 1839, 15 November 1839 and 30 November 1839.
J. Hutchinson & Son: Encloses extract of letter from Messrs. Roskell, Ogden & Co. of 24 May 1839 about stock brokerage.
Thomas Maingy: Investment in American securities.
T. Baring: Business affairs.

J. Bates (New York) to Baring Bros. & Co. Written on his arrival - Comments on several matters - United States Bank and Biddle - Webster and a National Bank - the cotton crop - T.W. Ward & his son Samuel G. - The Bank of Commerce - American stocks - Mr. Astor - Van Buren &c. Standing of Baring Bros. & Co.
Louis McLane To J. Bates. Enclosing detailed statement of Maryland State Loans, dated 12 October 1839.
Thomas Baring to J. Bates. Resume of General Hamilton's advocacy of the proposed Texas Loan - adding suggestions of his own with regard to the operation. N.B. A press copy is filed with this.
C.A. Davis to J. Bates - Political, financial and commercial comments - Introduce Mr. Forbes.
John Eliot Thayer to Baring Bros. & Co. Re Bank of United States Stock - Scathing remarks on Biddle and the Bank.
T. Wiggins & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Recommending John Adams Perkins of Montreal.
State of Ohio - Canal Loan.
Thos. Wilson & Co.: Payment on Mississippi bonds.
C.A. Davis to J. Bates - Financial situation - prophesies that early in the sessions steps will be taken to create a national currency &c.
C.W. King, Macao: Comments upon their business relations.
C.B. Young to J. Bates - Re business of the packets &c.
C.A. Davis: Expects defeat of Van Bures and creation of a Nationals Bank. Refers to cotton crop, securities market and other business matters.
Arch. Gracie: Money market; cotton crop.
Lord Ashburton to J. Bates - United States affairs.
M.T. Williams (Ohio Life Insurance & Trust Co.) to Baring Bros. & Co. Re affairs in Ohio - commercial and financial.
Arch. Gracie, Mobile: The cotton crop.
Manning & Marshall: Disposal of claim against Estates of the Marques of Aquayo.
Overend, Gurney & Co.: Referring to terms of the 200,000 pounds loan.
H.G. Runnels to T.W. Ward. Acknowledging instructions re valuing on cotton in the hands of Baring Bros. & Co. Statement of the Mississippi Union Bank.
Joseph Coolidge, Jr.: Sails for China; encloses letter from Aug. Heard with whom he expects to form partnership.

Baring Bros. & Co.'s statement of their transactions with Mr. Jaudon no reply to an article in New York Courier and Express of 31 March 1840, repeating an attack upon Mr. Bates and their firm. Signed - Baring Bros. & Co. N.B. A printed copy of this may be found in the printed matter under same date.
W.B. Lawrence: Stock of the American Life Insurance & Trust Company of Baltimore.
Arch. Gracie to J. Bates Enclosing statement of the Cotton Crop of the United States for the year ending 30 September 1839.
Unsigned memo re certain rules of action for the Banks &c.
M.T. Williams, Ohio Life Insurance & Trust Co.: Decline of cotton and flour prices. Business in a depressed state. Political news.
Grant & Stone to Baring Bros. & Co. Interesting description of the "final stopping" of the United States Bank - effect on other Banks and currency.
Wm. Appleton: Refers to the standing of various commercial houses.
Arch. Gracie to T.W. Ward: Cotton.
Maryland Act - To provide for the payment of the interest on the public debt of this State and for the conversion of its Sterling bonds into Currency debts.
Henry G. Chapman: Encloses statement of account.
W.M. Lambeth (W.M. Lambeth & Thompson, N.O.): Re bills drawn by Vincent Nolte on cotton shipments.
Memorandum of Louisiana State & City Bonds in the hands of Baring Bros. & Co. London, for account of the Union Bank of Louisiana.
Memo Unsigned - State Debts - Will posterity pay them?
J. Cryder: Enlarges on current situation in the United States and his private plans.
T. Baring to Baring Bros. & Co. Refers to a proposed establishment of a Trust and Loan Company in Canada upon the plan of that in New York.
